text:
[Cites 
16
, Cited by 
0
]

Calcutta High Court (Appellete Side)

Pawan Kumar Sharma vs Union Of India & Ors on 12 March, 2013

Author: 
Ashoke Kumar Dasadhikari

Bench: 
Ashoke Kumar Dasadhikari

 1

12.03.2013 C.O. 1793(W) of 1996
 ss
 Pawan Kumar Sharma
 Vs.
 Union of India & ors.

 Mr. Amar Nath Dhole
 Mr. Pinaki Dhole
 ... For the petitioner

 Mr. Arunava Ghosh
 Mr. Sudhanshu Sil
 Mr. Raj Kumar Basu
 ... For the Punjab National Bank

 Writ petition was filed questioning refusal to grant

 seniority to the petitioner, on the basis of Middle

 Management Group Scale-II.

 It was submitted by Mr. Pinaki Dhole, learned

 Counsel led by Mr. Amar Nath Dhole, learned Counsel

 appearing for the petitioner that the writ petitioner has

 made representation sometime in the year 1983 and

 thereafter it was disposed of in the year 1990 without

 granting appropriate relief to the writ petitioner.

 Thereafter, he made further representation before the

 higher authority and the higher authority replied that

 representation could not be considered at that stage in

 view of pendency of review application.

 Mr. Dhole submits even after dismissal of review
 2

petition the writ petitioner was not granted proper

seniority and scale. Hence the writ petitioner filed this writ

petition on 6th February, 1996.

 Mr. Dhole submits that the writ petitioner is claiming

the benefit of Middle Management Group Scale-II in the

New India Bank with effect from 19th September, 1997

when he was posted as manager on proposed sub-office at

Bhamukheri, district Ambala.

 Mr. Dhole also contends that the writ petitioner is

similarly placed with another employee namely, S.

Sainathan to whom all service benefits of Middle

Management Group Scale-II has been given with effect

from the date when he was posted as manager in the

proposed sub-office by virtue of the decision of the Hon'ble

High Court at Andhra Pradesh. He also submits that the

writ petitioner joined the post as Manager on 19th

September, 1977 and was confirmed to the said post on 1st

June, 1979. He submits, against the order of refusal for

consideration as communicated by letter dated 19th

February, 1990 the petitioner preferred an appeal on 3rd

March, 1990 against the impugned order of non-

consideration before the Chairman and the Director of the

bank.
 3

 The Hon'ble Supreme Court dismissed the review

petition on 5th March, 1993. Thereafter on 4th September,

1993 by a notification of the Reserve Bank of India, New

Bank of India amalgamated with the Punjab National

Bank. On 28th February, 1994 the petitioner once again

made representation before the General Manager

(Personnel), Punjab National Bank claiming fixation of his

seniority in Middle Management Group Scale-II with effect

from 19th September, 1977. Thereafter the writ petitioner

made several representations but to no effect.

 Mr. Dhole submits that the matter was heard by the

learned Single Judge and the writ petition was allowed in

favour of the writ petitioner. However, the Bank

authorities preferred an appeal before the Hon'ble Division

Bench. The Hon'ble Appeal Court remanded back the

matter mainly on two points, namely, i) whether after such

long delay, any relief could be granted to the writ petitioner

when admittedly the writ petitioner moved the writ

application in the year 1996 claiming his right of seniority

in the post of Middle Management Group Scale-II with

effect from 19th September, 1977; (ii) whether the case of

Sianathan is identical on the question of law as was urged

and the factual matrix of the case as has been pleaded by
 4

the writ petitioner.

 The Hon'ble Appeal Court recorded in Their

Lordships' judgement that no answer and no analysis of

those two issues were available in the learned Single

Judge's decision. However, the Hon'ble Appeal Court

remanded the matter to decide all the issues including the

point of maintainability of the writ petition.

 Mr. Dhole would contend the writ petitioner has

explained the delay. He further submits that there are

decisions in favour of the petitioner holding that if there

are sufficient explanation for the delay the writ petition

should not be dismissed on that ground. He also submits

that the point of delay is to be taken at the threshold but

in the instant case the point was not taken and the matter

has come after completion of all affidavits and this is the

third-round litigation before the Single Bench.

 Mr. Dhole cited the decisions in support of his

aforementioned contention. First one is reported in A.I.R.

1972 S.C. 908 (P.B. Roy Vs. Union of India); he has

referred paragraph 8 of the said judgement. Paragraph 8 of

the said judgement reads as follows :-

 "8. The learned Judge who had initially heard the
 petition had pointed out that the representation of the
 5

 Appellant was first rejected on 29-7-1960 and that it did
 not matter that the petitioner had continued making
 subsequent representations. The learned Judge had
 noticed the explanation that the petitioner could not
 approach the Court as he was admitted to a Tuberculosis
 Clinic in June, 1961. The learned Judge, having found
 that this was not sufficient to explain the delay between
 29-7-1960 and June 1961 was disposed to reject the
 petition on the ground of laches. But, in view of the
 decision of the majority of the Full Bench of the Punjab
 High Court in S. Gurmej Sing v. Election Tribunal,
 Gurdaspur, (1964) 6 Pun LR 589 = (AIR 1964 Punj 337)
 (FB) the delay in filing the petition was overlooked on the
 ground that, after the admission of a Writ Petition and
 hearing of arguments, the rule that delay may defeat the
 rights of a party is relaxed and need not be applied if his
 case is 'positive good'."

 The other judgement cited by Mr. Dhole is reported

in A.I.R. 1990 S.C. 1308 (The State of Madhya Pradesh Vs.

Bani Singh and another). Paragraph 8 of the

aforementioned judgement as referred by Mr. Dhole reads

as follows :-

 "8. The learned Counsel also contended that though
 Screening Committee met in 1979-80 the application
 under 
Section 19
 of the Administrative Tribunals Act was
 filed only on 19-12-1986 and that therefore the
 application should have been dismissed on the ground of
 delay and laches. The Tribunal considered this question
 in detail and held that since the representation for the
 year 1981 was pending till 1986 and there is an allegation
 6

 that the respondent had been making representation to

 the Government in this regard and in fact one such
 representation was accepted and it is on that basis in
 spite of the fact that the facts and situations remained
 the same in the 1982 and respondent was selected for
 selection grade with effect from 4-3-1982. In those
 circumstances the Tribunal said that they were not
 willing to dismiss the application on the ground of
 the laches and it has to be decided on merits. In
 these circumstances we are also unable to interfere
 with the order of the Tribunal."

 
The other decision cited by Mr. Dhole is A.I.R. 1990

Patna 11 (
Dr. Jagannath Mishrta Vs. State of Bihar and

others
). He has referred paragraph 17 which reads as

follows :-

 "17. 
In 
P.B. Roy v. Union of India
, AIR 1972 SC 908
 the Supreme Court itself had laid down that the 'delay in
 filing the petition under 
Article 226
 may be overlooked on
 the ground that, after the admission of a writ petition and
 hearing of arguments, the rule that delay may defeat the
 rights of a party is relaxed and need not be applied if his
 case is 'positively good'."

 Mr. Dhole submits that there is no delay or laches on

the side of the writ petitioner. Therefore, the point of delay

should be ignored by the Hon'ble Court in the facts and

circumstances of this case and since there are sufficient

explanation to it. It was also submitted that the case of
 S.

 7

Sainathan and the petitioner is standing on similar footing

and they are also similarly placed. Therefore, the benefit

which was given to S. Sainathan in view of Hon'ble

Andhara Pradesh High Court judgement should also be

given to the writ petitioner.

 Mr. Dhole contended there is similarity of S.

Sainathan with the writ petitioner regarding appointment

of both of them as Branch Manager. Therefore, they are

similarly situated.

 Mr. Dhole contended that in the affidavit-in-reply it

was specifically stated by the writ petitioner that he is

similarly situated as S. Sainathan.

 Learned Counsel submits that the respondents are

responsible for making such discrimination and denial of

the benefit to the writ petitioner, although he is entitled to

get the benefit with effect from 1977.

 Mr. Arunava Ghosh, learned Counsel appearing for

the respondent-Bank submits that there is inordinate

delay in filing the writ application. He submits that the

writ petitioner made the first representation in the year

1983 after the bank nationalisation effected on and from

15th April, 1981. He submits on 1st January, 1983 Officer

Regulation brought into operation. The writ petitioner

 8

opted for new scale. He was categorised in Junior

Management Group Scale-I as he was in scale of Rs.400 -

1020/- in accordance with the Regulation VII and placed

in the seniority list of that scale. So far other officers who

were working in the scale of Rs.500-1330/- were

categorised in the scale of Rs.1200-2000/- as Middle

Management Group Scale-II.

 According to Mr. Ghosh, all the officers of the bank

were categorised according to the Regulation VII. He also

submits apart from the categorisation as Junior

Management Group Scale-I or Middle Management Group

Scale-II, there are other categorisation also in other scale

which is not relevant for the present.

 Mr. Ghosh submits that S. Sainathan filed an appeal

within thirty days as per Regulation XIII of the Officers'

Service Regulation since he did not accept his position in

Junior Management Group Scale-I. On the other hand, not

only the petitioner did not file any such appeal, but also

accepted his fitment, grade and seniority and the writ

petitioner, in fact, clearly acquiesced him to a senior

position given to him and the fitment given in Junior

Management Group Scale-I.

 Mr. Ghosh submits the writ petitioner is estopped

 9

from challenging the action of the respondent authorities.

According to Mr. Ghosh, these are the facts which make

the case of the writ petitioner different from that of S.

Sainathan.

 Mr. Ghosh submits that S. Sainathan's case did not

lay any proposition of law that all the persons who are

senior to Sainathan should also be made Middle

Management Group Scale-II. He submits there is no such

observation either by Andha Pradesh High Court or by the

Hon'ble Apex Court.

 According to Mr. Ghosh, S. Sainathan's case has

been decided on its own fact and the benefit of that case is

not available to the writ petitioner or the writ petitioner is

also not entitled to claim such benefit.

 Mr. Ghosh submits that one retired officer of the

Bank namely, Sri R. D. Rao filed a contempt petition in the

Hon'ble Supreme Court after order dated 20th February,

1992, disposing of the bank's Special Leave Petition and

claimed similar relief. The said petition was dismissed by

the Hon'ble Supreme Court vide order dated 4th February,

1991. He submits that thereafter Mr. Rao filed a writ

petition under 
Article 32
 of the Constitution of India,

which was also dismissed by the Hon'ble Supreme Court

 10

vide order dated 17th January, 1994. Therefore, this

clearly shows that the benefit of the judgement in case of

S. Sainathan cannot be extended to others including the

petitioner. He submits the present writ petition is solely

based on the judgement of S. Sainathan and the writ

petition is misconceived. The same should be dismissed on

that ground.

 
Mr. Ghosh submits some other officers have also

filed the writ petition claiming similar relief, being CWP

5650 of 1984 (
K.B. Sharma and Ors. Vs. New Bank of

India
 & ors.). The learned Single Bench of Punjab and

Haryana High Court allowed the writ petition on 3rd

February, 1988. The erstwhile New Bank of India filed

appeal against the judgement and the said LPA 310 of

1988 was allowed by the Division Bench on 23rd March,

1990 and the judgement of the Hon'ble Single Bench was

set aside and the writ petition of the writ petitioners was

dismissed.

 Mr. Ghosh submits that the writ petitioner himself is

admitting that he was under scale Rs.400-1000/- which is

different from Branch Manager scale of Rs.500-1200/-.

The petitioner also admitted that he was posted at sub-

office and not in a branch office. It is also admitted by the

 11

petitioner that he could not achieve the deposit target and

as such his probation period is extended.

 Mr. Ghosh submits in the facts and circumstances of

this case it would appear that the writ petitioner has

accepted his fitment in Junior Management Group Scale-I

and was paid arrear of salary on account of revised

fitment. He submits after lapse of 13 years he filed the

writ petition challenging the said fitment, which was done

long 13 years ago.

 Mr. Ghosh submits the writ petitioner is estopped

from challenging the fitment, which was settled before 13

years. The writ petition was filed without any explanation

of inordinate delay and therefore, this writ petition should

be dismissed.

 Mr. Ghosh submits it would appear from the reply

under paragraph 8, filed by the writ petitioner, that

although he has raised a protest against the categorisation

and placement in Junior Management Group Scale-I in

1983 and he was not allowed to participate in March, 1985

promotion process as cut off date to complete 7 years as

per new guideline, he did not file the writ petition rather he

participated in the promotion process from Junior

Management Group Scale-I to Middle Management Group

 12

Scale-II on the basis of a call letter dated 25th January,

1991 and appeared before the Committee on 4th February,

1991 and got promotion as well as the grade with effect

from 1991.

 Mr. Ghosh submits that although he has accepted

1984 promotion list and also appeared in the selection

process in 1991 and further got the promotion in 1991 but

he made representation one after another without taking

any legal action either by filing a writ petition or any other

step against the respondent authorities. He submits that

all these actions on the side of the writ petitioner clearly

shows that he himself waived his claim after acceptance of

the promotion list prepared in 1984 and thereafter in

1992.

 According to Mr. Ghosh, the writ petitioner should

not be permitted to get the benefit of such fixation and

promotion.

 Mr. Ghosh submits that even after rejection of the

prayer in 1990 the writ petitioner did not come up before

this Court rather he participated in 1991 selection process

for having promotion. He submits that the writ petitioner

ought to have come in the year 1984 when he was not

allowed to appear in the promotion process and a different

 13

seniority list was prepared for Middle Management Group

Scale-II ignoring his claim as alleged by him rather he has

awaited for long 12 years after 1984 and challenged the

fitment by filing a writ petition only in 1996.

 Mr. Ghosh also submits that there is no explanation

for such delay save and except some reminders and

representations, which are of no effect or have no

enforceability. Mr. Ghosh also submits the judgement of

the Hon'ble High Court of Andhra Pradesh was delivered

on 13th January, 1987 but the writ petitioner did not file

the writ petition in 1987, he has waited till 1996 i.e. till

after disposal of the Special Leave Petition as well as

review petition in 1992. According to Mr. Ghosh the writ

petitioner was sitting on fence and as per the settled

principle of law as decided by the Hon'ble Apex Court the

writ petition should not be retained, when the person who

instead of challenging the impugned action, sat on fence

and only after the other person claiming some benefit

having been successful, have filed or instituted the present

proceeding.

 Mr. Ghosh submits that there are several

judgements in this regard. He also submits there is nine

Judges' Bench Supreme Court judgement delivered in case

 14

of Mafatlal wherein the Hon'ble Apex Court have decided,

the writ petition filed by a person who sitting on fence is

not entertainable after a long gap.

 Mr. Ghosh further submits that the officers who took

over charges over small branches or sub-branches got

their branches upgraded to the higher cadre for

recognition for their initiative, hard work and performance

and became eligible for higher allowance and pay scale

whereas the writ petitioner's case is different specially

when the petitioner's working in a sub-office could not

upgrade the status to a branch office cadre. Accordingly,

he is also not entitled to get the benefit.

 Mr. Ghosh produced a chart showing the difference

between S. Sainathan and P.K. Sharma, the petitioner. The

chart reads as follows :-

 A comparison between P.K. Sharma and S. Sainathan
 P.K. Sharma
 19.09.1977 - Appointed by New Bank of India Ltd. as
 Manager on probation at Sub office in Scale
 400-1020 (P.27)
 01.06.1979 - Confirmed Manager in Scale 400-1020
 (P.30)
 15.04.1981 - New Bank of India Ltd. was nationalized.
 01.01.1983 - Officers Service Regulations brought into
 operation. Sharma opted for new scales
 (P 109). He was categorized in JM Scale I

 15

 (P5) as he was in Scale 400-1020 (p.4) in
 accordance with 
Regulation 7
 (p.32) and
 placed in the seniority list of that scale
 (p.110)
 N.B. 
Regulation 7
 is at P. 133.

 March 1985 - Promotions made from JM Scale I
 1990-1991 to MM Scale II (p.110)
 1990-1991 - Sharma participated in promotion process
 and was promoted to MM Scale II (p.78).

 S. Sainathan
 01.01.1975 - Sl. No.256 appointed as Accounts Officer.
 14.07.1977 - Appointed as Accounts Officer in New Bank
 of India Ltd. (P.40) This was equivalent to
 JM Grade I (P.135,136)
 03.02.1981 - Selected for post of MM2(PP50,53,57,40,41)
 25.02.1981 - Sl. No. 256 Selected for post of MM2 (p.41)
 13.01.1984 - Seniority List of MM2 published Showing
 Sainathan below Sc. No.256
 According to Mr. Ghosh, under no circumstances the

writ petitioner is entitled to claim similarity with the other

employee, S. Sainathan who has become successful by the

order of Hon'ble Supreme Court, otherwise also he is not

entitled to get any such benefit specially when he has

waived his right to such seniority and fixation of pay scale

without challenging probation of promotion list in 1984

and also thereafter accepting his promotion finalised

through selection process in 1991 and moreover, waiting

for a long time without challenging the impugned actions

 16

for about 13 years.

 Mr. Ghosh cited few judgements in support of his

contention. He has cited the Appeal Court judgement

delivered by Radhuvir, J. and laid stress on the following

paragraph :-

 " The writ petitioner S.Sainathan was an Accounts Officer
 appointed on July 14, 1977. He seeks he be placed above
 S.No.256 in the list of seniority published on January 13,
 1984 relevant to MM2. Serial No.256 was appointed to the
 post of Accounts Officer on January 1, 1975. There was a
 selection held for the post of MM2 on February 3, 1981 in
 which Serial No.256 did not appear. Sainathan appeared
 and was selected. Serial No.256 was selected on
 February 25, 1981. On the above facts, under Clause 5
 of 
Regulation 18
 of New Bank of India Officers Service
 Regulation shall affect the seniority among themselves of
 the officers as existing immediately prior to the appointed
 date. Sainathan was directed to be placed above
 Sl.No.256 in the seniority list of January 13, 1984. Such
 a conclusion reached, is assailed by the Bank in this
 appeal.

 The learned counsel for the Bank at first argued
 Sainathan could have made a representation to the
 Appellate Authority constituted to consider the dispute,
 therefore, he should not be permitted to approach this
 Court. It may not be necessary to consider this aspect for
 it is represented the Committee was formed in January,
 1986. The writ petition was filed earlier to that date.

 The learned counsel for the bank next argued
 seniority under the Regulations of 1982 is determined
 with reference to scale of pay, therefore, what is ordered

 17

 to the Bank is contrary to the Regulations of 1982. The
 selections referred to are earlier to the enforcement of
 regulations. Since Sainathan was selected on February 3,
 1981, it cannot be he will be junior to Sl.No. 256 selected
 on February 25, 1981.

 We, therefore, see no reason to interfere with the
 order under appeal. The direction for implementation is
 extended by four weeks from today.

 Writ appeal is dismissed at admission stage."

 
Mr. Ghosh then cited another judgement reported in

A.I.R. 1970 S.C. 470 (
Rabindra Nath Bose and others Vs.

Union of India and others
). Paragraph 36 of that

judgement reads as follows :-

 "36. Learned Counsel for the petitioners, however, says
 that there has been no undue delay. He says that the
 representations were being received by the Government
 all the time. But there is a limit to the time which can be
 considered reasonable for making representations. If the
 Government has turned down one representation, the
 making of another representation on similar lines would
 not enable the petitioners to explain the delay. Learned
 counsel for the petitioners says that the petitioners were
 under the impression that the Departmental Promotion
 Committee had held a meeting in 1948 and not on April
 29, 1949, and the real true facts came to be known in
 1961, when the Government mentioned these facts in
 their letter dated December 28, 1961. We are unable to
 accept this explanation. This fact has been mentioned in
 the minutes of the meeting of the Committee which met in
 February 1952 and we are unable to believe that the
 petitioners did not come to know all these facts till 1961.

 18

 But even assuming that the petitioners came to know all
 these facts only in December 1961, even then there has
 been inordinate delay in presenting the present petition.
 The fact that Jaisinghani's case, 1967-2 SCR 703 = (AIR
 1967 SC 1427) was pending before the High Court and
 later in this Court is also no excuse for the delay in
 presenting the present petition. In the result, the petition
 fails and is dismissed. There will be no order as to costs."

 Mr. Ghosh then cited a decision reported in A.I.R.

1989 S.C. 690 (Union of India and others Vs. M/s. Suksha

International and M/s. Nutan Gems and another).

Paragraph 11 of the aforementioned judgement as referred

by Mr. Ghosh reads as follows :-

 "11. Shri Subba Rao would say that the reference in
 the order by learned single Judge to the contention on the
 point of delay as bar to relief had nothing to9 do with the
 specific contention of the appellants that there was
 inordinate and unexplained delay in approaching the
 Court. This learned counsel submits, would be clear, by
 a reference to the aspect of the delay dealt with and
 considered in W.P. 2477 of 1984, on which the learned
 single Judge relied. The order of the same learned single
 Judge in W.P. 2477 of 1984, in which the particular
 aspect of delay is considered is at para 8 of that order.
 That para in the order in W.P. 2477 of 1984 reads :

 'Mr. Joshi, learned counsel for the respondents,
 submitted that the petitioners were not entitled
 to relief because of delay. It is not possible to
 agree. After the redemption certificate of 16th
 November, 1983, application for revalidation

 19

 and OGL endorsement was made within four
 months therefrom on 12th March, 1984. There
 is, in the circumstances, no such delay as to
 warrant its rejection on that ground. The
 contention thus fails and is rejected.' "

 
Mr. Ghosh also referred another judgement cited in

A.I.R.1989 S.C. 2082 (
T.R. Kapoor and others Vs. State of

Haryana and others
). The relevant portion of the

judgement which was referred by Mr. Ghosh reads as

follows :-

 " Held that the petitioners had acquiesced in the
 interpretation of the Rules by the State Government all
 along and it was only after the decision of the Supreme
 Court disapproving the interpretation placed by the State
 on the Rules they chose to move the Supreme Court
 under 
Art. 32
 of the Constitution to seek promotional
 benefits. Having remained complacent for a long number
 of years, the petitioners cannot now turn round and say
 that notwithstanding their inaction, they should be
 granted promotion from deemed dates on the basis of
 seniority."

 The other judgement cited by Mr. Ghosh is reported

in (2010) 7 S.C.C. 525 (Maresh Kumar Vs. Department of

Atomic Energy and others). Paragraph 15 of the said

judgement reads as follows :-

 "15. Merely because the case of the appellant was
 forwarded by the Department vide its Letter dated 27-1-
 2007 for favourable consideration, would not vest any

 20

 right in the petitioner and can hardly be of any materials
 consequence. If an employee keeps making representation
 after representation which are consistently rejected then
 the appellant cannot claim any relief on that ground. We
 are unable to find any merit in the contention raised
 before us and we are also of the view that the High Court
 was not in error while dismissing the writ petition even on
 the ground of unexplained delay and laches. The
 representation of the appellant was rejected as back in
 the year 1999 and for the reasons best known to the
 appellant he did not challenge the same before the court
 of competent jurisdiction."

 
Mr. Ghosh also cited the decision of the Hon'ble Apex

Court reported in (2006) 4 S.C.C. 327 (
Kerala Samsthana

Chethu Thozhilali Union Vs. State of Kerala and others
).

Relevant paragraphs 8, 9 and 10 read as follows :-

 
"8. It would be appropriate to note certain decisions
 of this Court in which this aspect has been dealt with in
 relation to 
Article 32
 of the Constitution. It is apparent
 that what has been stated as regards that article would
 apply, a fortiori, to 
Article 226.
 It was observed in
 
Rabindranath Bose v. Union of India
 that no relief can be
 given to the petitioner who without any reasonable
 explanation approaches this Court under 
Article 32
 after
 inordinate delay. It was stated that though 
Article 32
 is
 itself a guaranteed right, it does not follow from this that
 it was the intention of the Constitution-makers that this
 Court should disregard all principles and grant relief in
 petitions filed after inordinate delay.

 
9. It was stated in 
State of M.P. v. Nandlal Jaiswal

 that the High Court in exercise of its discretion

 21

 does not ordinarily assist the tardy and the
 indolent or the acquiescent and the lethargic. If
 there is inordinate delay on the part of the
 petitioner and such delay is not satisfactorily
 explained, the High Court may decline to
 intervene and grant relief in exercise of its writ
 jurisdiction. It was stated that this rule is
 premised on a number of factors. The High Court
 does not ordinarily permit a belated resort to the
 extraordinary remedy because it is likely to cause
 confusion and public inconvenience and bring, in
 its train new injustices, and if writ jurisdiction is
 exercised after unreasonable delay, it may have
 the effect of inflicting not only hardship and
 inconvenience but also injustice on third parties.
 It was pointed out that when writ jurisdiction is
 invoked, unexplained delay coupled with the
 creation of third-party rights in the meantime is
 an important factor which also weighs with the
 High Court in deciding whether or not to exercise
 such jurisdiction.

10. It has been pointed out by this Court in a number
 of cases that representations would not be
 adequate explanation to take care of delay. This
 was first stated in K.V. Rajalakshmiah Setty v.

 
State of Mysore. This was reiterated in
 
Rabindranath Bose
 case by stating that there is a
 limit to the time which can be considered
 reasonable for making representations and if the
 government had turned down one representation
 the making of another representation on similar
 lines will not explain the delay.
 
In 
State of Orissa
 v. Pyarimohan Samantaray
 making of repeated

 22

 representations was not regarded as satisfactory
 explanation of the delay. In that case the petition
 had been dismissed for delay alone."

 
The last judgement cited by Mr. Ghose is A.I.R. 1974

S.C. 2271 (
P.S. Sadasivaswamy Vs. State of Tamil Nadu
).

The relevant passage placed by Mr. Ghose reads as

follows :-

 " Brief Note :- (A) Where a Government servant slept
 over the promotions of his juniors over his head for
 fourteen years and then approached the High Court with
 writ petition challenging the relaxation of relevant rules in
 favour of the juniors, the writ petition is liable to be
 dismissed in limine. Such an aggrieved person should
 approach the Court at least within six months or at the
 most a year of promotion of his juniors.

 It is not that there is any period of limitation for
 the Courts to exercise their powers under 
Art. 226
, nor is
 it that there can never be a case where the Courts cannot
 interfere in a matter after the passage of a certain length
 of time. But it would be a sound and wise exercise of
 discretion for the Courts to refuse to exercise their
 extraordinary powers under 
Art. 226
 in the case of
 persons who do not approach it expeditiously for relief and
 who stand by and allow things to happen and then
 approach the Court to put forward stale claims and try to
 unsettle settled matters. Decision in W.P. and Appeal
 (Mad.) ...... ".

 I have carefully considered the submissions made by

the learned Counsel appearing for the respective parties as

 23

well as the materials available on record. It appears from

records that the writ petitioner was appointed as Manager

on probation at sub-office in scale of 400-1020/- on 19th

Septembers, 1977. He was confirmed after about two

years i.e. on 1st June, 1979 in the scale of Rs.400-1020/-.

In view of Bank Nationalization Act, the respondent, the

New Bank of India, the employer of the writ petitioner, was

also nationalised on 15th April, 1981. Officers Service

Regulations brought into operation on and from 1st

January, 1983. Categorisation was made pursuant to such

regulation and the writ petitioner was categorised in

Junior Management Group Scale-I and placed in the

seniority list on that scale. The petitioner made

representation in July 25, 1983 against Categorisation.

The concerned respondent thereafter prepared the

seniority list on 1st January, 1994. The respondent also

did not allow the writ petitioner to participate in the

promotion process held in March, 1985 but the writ

petitioner did not question the same before any court of

law rather he made another representation in June 24,

1984. Thereafter, again he made appeal for fitment in

Middle Management Group Scale-II on 1st July, 1987.

However, the respondent authorities issued a letter of

 24

refusal on 19th February, 1990. The writ petitioner then

also remained silent. Thereafter, the selection process was

held for giving promotion and on the basis of invitation of

the respondent authorities the writ petitioner participated

in the promotion process from Junior Management Group

Scale-I to Middle Management Group Scale-II and he was

selected and he got promotion as well as grade to Middle

Management Group Scale-II. Thereafter, he once again

made an appeal before the higher authorities i.e. before the

Chairman and the Managing Director on October 31, 1992

and the respondent Bank replied to the representation of

the writ petitioner stating therein the reply dated 9th

November, 1992 that against the decision of Sainathan

they have preferred a review application before the Hon'ble

Apex Court which is pending. Therefore, the case cannot

be considered at that stage. The review application was

again rejected by the Hon'ble Supreme Court on 5th March,

1993 and the writ petitioner asked the concerned

respondent to reconsider his case. However, the writ

petitioner at that stage even did not come up before the

Hon'ble Court questioning the action on the side of the

respondent. The writ petitioner thereafter again made

representation and has waited till January, 1996 and only

 25

in February, 1996 filed this writ petition claiming seniority

and gradation with effect from 19th September, 1977 on

the basis of the decision of S. Sainathan. Although

Sainathan's case was decided by Andhra Pradesh High

Court in 1987 the writ petitioner also did not question the

action of the respondent authorities after 1987. In this

way the writ petitioner continued in the promotional post

and got all subsequent benefits on that basis and in fact,

retired from service after completion of the entire service

tenure. It appears from the aforementioned action that the

cause of action in fact arose in 1984 when he was not

called for participation in promotion process and when his

seniority list was prepared in the category of Junior Group

Scale-I. He also did not come up and question the same in

1987. The learned Single Judge delivered in 1987 in

Sainathan's case. The writ petitioner also did not come

and question the action of the respondent authorities on

the basis of the said judgement. He waited for a long

thirteen years till before February, 1996. There is no

acceptable explanation for the delay in the writ petition.

Further making repeated representations without taking

any legal action in appropriate time, is not at all an

explanation for the delay. In case of Naresh Kumar (supra)

 26

the Hon'ble Supreme Court have clearly held that if an

employee keeps making representation after representation

which are consistently rejected then the appellant cannot

claim any relief on that ground and the Hon'ble Apex

Court refused to grant any relief in favour of the aggrieved

party. 
In case of 
Keralasamsthana Chethu Thozhilali

Union
 (supra) it was held if the writ jurisdiction is

exercised after unreasonable delay, it may have the effect

of inflicting not only hardship and inconvenience but also

injustice on third parties. It was also pointed out that

when the writ jurisdiction is invoked, unexplained delay

coupled with the creation of third-party rights in the

meantime is an important factor which also weighs with

the High Court in deciding whether or not to exercise such

jurisdiction.

 In my view, the writ petitioner went on making

representation one after another and at the same time has

accepted the categorisation in Junior Management Group

Scale-I and also accepted promotion given by the

respondent-Bank in 1991 and continued till the date of

retirement. Only after a lapse of 13 years he made this

writ petition taking a plea of similar status with Sainathan

and claimed relief with effect from 1977. In my view, the

 27

writ petitioner suffers inordinate unexplained delay.

Therefore, the writ petition is not maintainable.

 It is pertinent to mention that after the refusal of

consideration of representation in 1990 the writ petitioner

at the call of the respondent authorities appeared at the

promotional process and having been selected accepted

such promotion with effect from 1991. Although he has

made some representations thereafter but it appears that

he has waived all his rights by accepting such promotion

and also by not questioning the impugned action in 1984

when the promotional list was prepared and thereafter in

1987 when the judgement was delivered in case of

Sainathan and thereafter when the process of selection

started in 1991 for giving promotion.

 In that view of the matter the writ petitioner loses his

claim to have any benefit on and from 1977.

 On the point of similarity in status and claiming

similar benefits as was given to Sainathan is concerned,

from a bare perusal of the writ petition as well as reply, the

writ petitioner could not explain before this Court in what

manner he is similarly situated. However, an argument

was advanced that the writ petitioner is similarly situated

like S. Sainathan but the comparison between 
S.

 28

Sainathan and P.K. Sharma as submitted by Mr. Ghosh

makes some difference and distinction between them.

Therefore, on that score also the writ petitioner is not

entitled to get any benefit. Otherwise also it appears that

on similar ground some other employees moved an

application under 
Article 32
 of the Constitution before the

Hon'ble Apex Court to have the same benefit which was

dismissed by the Hon'ble Apex Court. There is other

proceeding also which was initiated by some other

employees before Punjab and Haryana High Court, which

was although allowed by the learned Single Judge but

subsequently the order of the learned Single Judge was set

aside and the writ petition was dismissed.

 In view of my aforementioned findings this writ

petition must fail. Therefore, the writ petition is dismissed.

However, there would be no order as to costs.

 Urgent photostat certified copy of this order, if

applied for, be furnished to the appearing parties on

priority basis.

 (Ashoke Kumar Dasadhikari, J.)

paragraphs.text:
[Cites 
16
, Cited by 
0
]
Calcutta High Court (Appellete Side)
Pawan Kumar Sharma vs Union Of India & Ors on 12 March, 2013

Author: 
Ashoke Kumar Dasadhikari

Bench: 
Ashoke Kumar Dasadhikari

12.03.2013 C.O. 1793(W) of 1996
 ss
 Pawan Kumar Sharma
 Vs.
 Union of India & ors.

Mr. Amar Nath Dhole
 Mr. Pinaki Dhole
 ... For the petitioner

Mr. Arunava Ghosh
 Mr. Sudhanshu Sil
 Mr. Raj Kumar Basu
 ... For the Punjab National Bank
Writ petition was filed questioning refusal to grant
seniority to the petitioner, on the basis of Middle
Management Group Scale-II.
It was submitted by Mr. Pinaki Dhole, learned
Counsel led by Mr. Amar Nath Dhole, learned Counsel
appearing for the petitioner that the writ petitioner has
made representation sometime in the year 1983 and
thereafter it was disposed of in the year 1990 without
granting appropriate relief to the writ petitioner.
Thereafter, he made further representation before the
higher authority and the higher authority replied that
representation could not be considered at that stage in
view of pendency of review application.

Mr. Dhole submits even after dismissal of review
 2
petition the writ petitioner was not granted proper
seniority and scale. Hence the writ petitioner filed this writ
petition on 6th February, 1996.
Mr. Dhole submits that the writ petitioner is claiming
the benefit of Middle Management Group Scale-II in the
New India Bank with effect from 19th September, 1997
when he was posted as manager on proposed sub-office at
Bhamukheri, district Ambala.
Mr. Dhole also contends that the writ petitioner is
similarly placed with another employee namely, S.
Sainathan to whom all service benefits of Middle
Management Group Scale-II has been given with effect
from the date when he was posted as manager in the
proposed sub-office by virtue of the decision of the Hon'ble
High Court at Andhra Pradesh. He also submits that the
writ petitioner joined the post as Manager on 19th
September, 1977 and was confirmed to the said post on 1st
June, 1979. He submits, against the order of refusal for
consideration as communicated by letter dated 19th
February, 1990 the petitioner preferred an appeal on 3rd
March, 1990 against the impugned order of non-
consideration before the Chairman and the Director of the

bank.
 3
The Hon'ble Supreme Court dismissed the review
petition on 5th March, 1993. Thereafter on 4th September,
1993 by a notification of the Reserve Bank of India, New
Bank of India amalgamated with the Punjab National
Bank. On 28th February, 1994 the petitioner once again
made representation before the General Manager
(Personnel), Punjab National Bank claiming fixation of his
seniority in Middle Management Group Scale-II with effect
from 19th September, 1977. Thereafter the writ petitioner
made several representations but to no effect.
Mr. Dhole submits that the matter was heard by the
learned Single Judge and the writ petition was allowed in
favour of the writ petitioner. However, the Bank
authorities preferred an appeal before the Hon'ble Division
Bench. The Hon'ble Appeal Court remanded back the
matter mainly on two points, namely, i) whether after such
long delay, any relief could be granted to the writ petitioner
when admittedly the writ petitioner moved the writ
application in the year 1996 claiming his right of seniority
in the post of Middle Management Group Scale-II with
effect from 19th September, 1977; (ii) whether the case of
Sianathan is identical on the question of law as was urged

and the factual matrix of the case as has been pleaded by
 4
the writ petitioner.
The Hon'ble Appeal Court recorded in Their
Lordships' judgement that no answer and no analysis of
those two issues were available in the learned Single
Judge's decision. However, the Hon'ble Appeal Court
remanded the matter to decide all the issues including the
point of maintainability of the writ petition.
Mr. Dhole would contend the writ petitioner has
explained the delay. He further submits that there are
decisions in favour of the petitioner holding that if there
are sufficient explanation for the delay the writ petition
should not be dismissed on that ground. He also submits
that the point of delay is to be taken at the threshold but
in the instant case the point was not taken and the matter
has come after completion of all affidavits and this is the
third-round litigation before the Single Bench.
Mr. Dhole cited the decisions in support of his
aforementioned contention. First one is reported in A.I.R.
1972 S.C. 908 (P.B. Roy Vs. Union of India); he has
referred paragraph 8 of the said judgement. Paragraph 8 of
the said judgement reads as follows :-

"8. The learned Judge who had initially heard the
 petition had pointed out that the representation of the
 5

Appellant was first rejected on 29-7-1960 and that it did
 not matter that the petitioner had continued making
 subsequent representations. The learned Judge had
 noticed the explanation that the petitioner could not
 approach the Court as he was admitted to a Tuberculosis
 Clinic in June, 1961. The learned Judge, having found
 that this was not sufficient to explain the delay between
 29-7-1960 and June 1961 was disposed to reject the
 petition on the ground of laches. But, in view of the
 decision of the majority of the Full Bench of the Punjab
 High Court in S. Gurmej Sing v. Election Tribunal,
 Gurdaspur, (1964) 6 Pun LR 589 = (AIR 1964 Punj 337)
 (FB) the delay in filing the petition was overlooked on the
 ground that, after the admission of a Writ Petition and
 hearing of arguments, the rule that delay may defeat the
 rights of a party is relaxed and need not be applied if his
 case is 'positive good'."
The other judgement cited by Mr. Dhole is reported
in A.I.R. 1990 S.C. 1308 (The State of Madhya Pradesh Vs.
Bani Singh and another). Paragraph 8 of the
aforementioned judgement as referred by Mr. Dhole reads
as follows :-

"8. The learned Counsel also contended that though
 Screening Committee met in 1979-80 the application
 under 
Section 19
 of the Administrative Tribunals Act was
 filed only on 19-12-1986 and that therefore the
 application should have been dismissed on the ground of
 delay and laches. The Tribunal considered this question
 in detail and held that since the representation for the
 year 1981 was pending till 1986 and there is an allegation
 6
that the respondent had been making representation to

the Government in this regard and in fact one such
 representation was accepted and it is on that basis in
 spite of the fact that the facts and situations remained
 the same in the 1982 and respondent was selected for
 selection grade with effect from 4-3-1982. In those
 circumstances the Tribunal said that they were not
 willing to dismiss the application on the ground of
 the laches and it has to be decided on merits. In
 these circumstances we are also unable to interfere
 with the order of the Tribunal."
The other decision cited by Mr. Dhole is A.I.R. 1990

Patna 11 (
Dr. Jagannath Mishrta Vs. State of Bihar and

others
). He has referred paragraph 17 which reads as
follows :-

"17. 
In 
P.B. Roy v. Union of India
, AIR 1972 SC 908
 the Supreme Court itself had laid down that the 'delay in
 filing the petition under 
Article 226
 may be overlooked on
 the ground that, after the admission of a writ petition and
 hearing of arguments, the rule that delay may defeat the
 rights of a party is relaxed and need not be applied if his
 case is 'positively good'."
Mr. Dhole submits that there is no delay or laches on
the side of the writ petitioner. Therefore, the point of delay
should be ignored by the Hon'ble Court in the facts and
circumstances of this case and since there are sufficient

explanation to it. It was also submitted that the case of
 S.
Sainathan and the petitioner is standing on similar footing
and they are also similarly placed. Therefore, the benefit
which was given to S. Sainathan in view of Hon'ble
Andhara Pradesh High Court judgement should also be
given to the writ petitioner.
Mr. Dhole contended there is similarity of S.
Sainathan with the writ petitioner regarding appointment
of both of them as Branch Manager. Therefore, they are
similarly situated.
Mr. Dhole contended that in the affidavit-in-reply it
was specifically stated by the writ petitioner that he is
similarly situated as S. Sainathan.
Learned Counsel submits that the respondents are
responsible for making such discrimination and denial of
the benefit to the writ petitioner, although he is entitled to
get the benefit with effect from 1977.
Mr. Arunava Ghosh, learned Counsel appearing for
the respondent-Bank submits that there is inordinate
delay in filing the writ application. He submits that the
writ petitioner made the first representation in the year
1983 after the bank nationalisation effected on and from
15th April, 1981. He submits on 1st January, 1983 Officer
Regulation brought into operation. The writ petitioner
opted for new scale. He was categorised in Junior
Management Group Scale-I as he was in scale of Rs.400 -
1020/- in accordance with the Regulation VII and placed
in the seniority list of that scale. So far other officers who
were working in the scale of Rs.500-1330/- were
categorised in the scale of Rs.1200-2000/- as Middle
Management Group Scale-II.
According to Mr. Ghosh, all the officers of the bank
were categorised according to the Regulation VII. He also
submits apart from the categorisation as Junior
Management Group Scale-I or Middle Management Group
Scale-II, there are other categorisation also in other scale
which is not relevant for the present.
Mr. Ghosh submits that S. Sainathan filed an appeal
within thirty days as per Regulation XIII of the Officers'
Service Regulation since he did not accept his position in
Junior Management Group Scale-I. On the other hand, not
only the petitioner did not file any such appeal, but also
accepted his fitment, grade and seniority and the writ
petitioner, in fact, clearly acquiesced him to a senior
position given to him and the fitment given in Junior
Management Group Scale-I.
Mr. Ghosh submits the writ petitioner is estopped
from challenging the action of the respondent authorities.
According to Mr. Ghosh, these are the facts which make
the case of the writ petitioner different from that of S.
Sainathan.
Mr. Ghosh submits that S. Sainathan's case did not
lay any proposition of law that all the persons who are
senior to Sainathan should also be made Middle
Management Group Scale-II. He submits there is no such
observation either by Andha Pradesh High Court or by the
Hon'ble Apex Court.
According to Mr. Ghosh, S. Sainathan's case has
been decided on its own fact and the benefit of that case is
not available to the writ petitioner or the writ petitioner is
also not entitled to claim such benefit.
Mr. Ghosh submits that one retired officer of the
Bank namely, Sri R. D. Rao filed a contempt petition in the
Hon'ble Supreme Court after order dated 20th February,
1992, disposing of the bank's Special Leave Petition and
claimed similar relief. The said petition was dismissed by
the Hon'ble Supreme Court vide order dated 4th February,
1991. He submits that thereafter Mr. Rao filed a writ

petition under 
Article 32
 of the Constitution of India,
which was also dismissed by the Hon'ble Supreme Court
vide order dated 17th January, 1994. Therefore, this
clearly shows that the benefit of the judgement in case of
S. Sainathan cannot be extended to others including the
petitioner. He submits the present writ petition is solely
based on the judgement of S. Sainathan and the writ
petition is misconceived. The same should be dismissed on
that ground.
Mr. Ghosh submits some other officers have also
filed the writ petition claiming similar relief, being CWP

5650 of 1984 (
K.B. Sharma and Ors. Vs. New Bank of

India
 & ors.). The learned Single Bench of Punjab and
Haryana High Court allowed the writ petition on 3rd
February, 1988. The erstwhile New Bank of India filed
appeal against the judgement and the said LPA 310 of
1988 was allowed by the Division Bench on 23rd March,
1990 and the judgement of the Hon'ble Single Bench was
set aside and the writ petition of the writ petitioners was
dismissed.
Mr. Ghosh submits that the writ petitioner himself is
admitting that he was under scale Rs.400-1000/- which is
different from Branch Manager scale of Rs.500-1200/-.
The petitioner also admitted that he was posted at sub-
office and not in a branch office. It is also admitted by the
petitioner that he could not achieve the deposit target and
as such his probation period is extended.
Mr. Ghosh submits in the facts and circumstances of
this case it would appear that the writ petitioner has
accepted his fitment in Junior Management Group Scale-I
and was paid arrear of salary on account of revised
fitment. He submits after lapse of 13 years he filed the
writ petition challenging the said fitment, which was done
long 13 years ago.
Mr. Ghosh submits the writ petitioner is estopped
from challenging the fitment, which was settled before 13
years. The writ petition was filed without any explanation
of inordinate delay and therefore, this writ petition should
be dismissed.
Mr. Ghosh submits it would appear from the reply
under paragraph 8, filed by the writ petitioner, that
although he has raised a protest against the categorisation
and placement in Junior Management Group Scale-I in
1983 and he was not allowed to participate in March, 1985
promotion process as cut off date to complete 7 years as
per new guideline, he did not file the writ petition rather he
participated in the promotion process from Junior
Management Group Scale-I to Middle Management Group
Scale-II on the basis of a call letter dated 25th January,
1991 and appeared before the Committee on 4th February,
1991 and got promotion as well as the grade with effect
from 1991.
Mr. Ghosh submits that although he has accepted
1984 promotion list and also appeared in the selection
process in 1991 and further got the promotion in 1991 but
he made representation one after another without taking
any legal action either by filing a writ petition or any other
step against the respondent authorities. He submits that
all these actions on the side of the writ petitioner clearly
shows that he himself waived his claim after acceptance of
the promotion list prepared in 1984 and thereafter in
According to Mr. Ghosh, the writ petitioner should
not be permitted to get the benefit of such fixation and
promotion.
Mr. Ghosh submits that even after rejection of the
prayer in 1990 the writ petitioner did not come up before
this Court rather he participated in 1991 selection process
for having promotion. He submits that the writ petitioner
ought to have come in the year 1984 when he was not
allowed to appear in the promotion process and a different
seniority list was prepared for Middle Management Group
Scale-II ignoring his claim as alleged by him rather he has
awaited for long 12 years after 1984 and challenged the
fitment by filing a writ petition only in 1996.
Mr. Ghosh also submits that there is no explanation
for such delay save and except some reminders and
representations, which are of no effect or have no
enforceability. Mr. Ghosh also submits the judgement of
the Hon'ble High Court of Andhra Pradesh was delivered
on 13th January, 1987 but the writ petitioner did not file
the writ petition in 1987, he has waited till 1996 i.e. till
after disposal of the Special Leave Petition as well as
review petition in 1992. According to Mr. Ghosh the writ
petitioner was sitting on fence and as per the settled
principle of law as decided by the Hon'ble Apex Court the
writ petition should not be retained, when the person who
instead of challenging the impugned action, sat on fence
and only after the other person claiming some benefit
having been successful, have filed or instituted the present
proceeding.
Mr. Ghosh submits that there are several
judgements in this regard. He also submits there is nine
Judges' Bench Supreme Court judgement delivered in case
of Mafatlal wherein the Hon'ble Apex Court have decided,
the writ petition filed by a person who sitting on fence is
not entertainable after a long gap.
Mr. Ghosh further submits that the officers who took
over charges over small branches or sub-branches got
their branches upgraded to the higher cadre for
recognition for their initiative, hard work and performance
and became eligible for higher allowance and pay scale
whereas the writ petitioner's case is different specially
when the petitioner's working in a sub-office could not
upgrade the status to a branch office cadre. Accordingly,
he is also not entitled to get the benefit.
Mr. Ghosh produced a chart showing the difference
between S. Sainathan and P.K. Sharma, the petitioner. The
chart reads as follows :-

A comparison between P.K. Sharma and S. Sainathan
 P.K. Sharma
 19.09.1977 - Appointed by New Bank of India Ltd. as
 Manager on probation at Sub office in Scale
 400-1020 (P.27)
 01.06.1979 - Confirmed Manager in Scale 400-1020
 (P.30)
 15.04.1981 - New Bank of India Ltd. was nationalized.
 01.01.1983 - Officers Service Regulations brought into
 operation. Sharma opted for new scales
 (P 109). He was categorized in JM Scale I

(P5) as he was in Scale 400-1020 (p.4) in
 accordance with 
Regulation 7
 (p.32) and
 placed in the seniority list of that scale
 (p.110)
 N.B. 
Regulation 7
 is at P. 133.

March 1985 - Promotions made from JM Scale I
 1990-1991 to MM Scale II (p.110)
 1990-1991 - Sharma participated in promotion process
 and was promoted to MM Scale II (p.78).

S. Sainathan
 01.01.1975 - Sl. No.256 appointed as Accounts Officer.
 14.07.1977 - Appointed as Accounts Officer in New Bank
 of India Ltd. (P.40) This was equivalent to
 JM Grade I (P.135,136)
 03.02.1981 - Selected for post of MM2(PP50,53,57,40,41)
 25.02.1981 - Sl. No. 256 Selected for post of MM2 (p.41)
 13.01.1984 - Seniority List of MM2 published Showing
 Sainathan below Sc. No.256
 According to Mr. Ghosh, under no circumstances the
writ petitioner is entitled to claim similarity with the other
employee, S. Sainathan who has become successful by the
order of Hon'ble Supreme Court, otherwise also he is not
entitled to get any such benefit specially when he has
waived his right to such seniority and fixation of pay scale
without challenging probation of promotion list in 1984
and also thereafter accepting his promotion finalised
through selection process in 1991 and moreover, waiting
for a long time without challenging the impugned actions
for about 13 years.
Mr. Ghosh cited few judgements in support of his
contention. He has cited the Appeal Court judgement
delivered by Radhuvir, J. and laid stress on the following
paragraph :-

" The writ petitioner S.Sainathan was an Accounts Officer
 appointed on July 14, 1977. He seeks he be placed above
 S.No.256 in the list of seniority published on January 13,
 1984 relevant to MM2. Serial No.256 was appointed to the
 post of Accounts Officer on January 1, 1975. There was a
 selection held for the post of MM2 on February 3, 1981 in
 which Serial No.256 did not appear. Sainathan appeared
 and was selected. Serial No.256 was selected on
 February 25, 1981. On the above facts, under Clause 5
 of 
Regulation 18
 of New Bank of India Officers Service
 Regulation shall affect the seniority among themselves of
 the officers as existing immediately prior to the appointed
 date. Sainathan was directed to be placed above
 Sl.No.256 in the seniority list of January 13, 1984. Such
 a conclusion reached, is assailed by the Bank in this
 appeal.

The learned counsel for the Bank at first argued
 Sainathan could have made a representation to the
 Appellate Authority constituted to consider the dispute,
 therefore, he should not be permitted to approach this
 Court. It may not be necessary to consider this aspect for
 it is represented the Committee was formed in January,
 1986. The writ petition was filed earlier to that date.

The learned counsel for the bank next argued
 seniority under the Regulations of 1982 is determined
 with reference to scale of pay, therefore, what is ordered

to the Bank is contrary to the Regulations of 1982. The
 selections referred to are earlier to the enforcement of
 regulations. Since Sainathan was selected on February 3,
 1981, it cannot be he will be junior to Sl.No. 256 selected
 on February 25, 1981.

We, therefore, see no reason to interfere with the
 order under appeal. The direction for implementation is
 extended by four weeks from today.
Writ appeal is dismissed at admission stage."
Mr. Ghosh then cited another judgement reported in

A.I.R. 1970 S.C. 470 (
Rabindra Nath Bose and others Vs.

Union of India and others
). Paragraph 36 of that
judgement reads as follows :-

"36. Learned Counsel for the petitioners, however, says
 that there has been no undue delay. He says that the
 representations were being received by the Government
 all the time. But there is a limit to the time which can be
 considered reasonable for making representations. If the
 Government has turned down one representation, the
 making of another representation on similar lines would
 not enable the petitioners to explain the delay. Learned
 counsel for the petitioners says that the petitioners were
 under the impression that the Departmental Promotion
 Committee had held a meeting in 1948 and not on April
 29, 1949, and the real true facts came to be known in
 1961, when the Government mentioned these facts in
 their letter dated December 28, 1961. We are unable to
 accept this explanation. This fact has been mentioned in
 the minutes of the meeting of the Committee which met in
 February 1952 and we are unable to believe that the
 petitioners did not come to know all these facts till 1961.

But even assuming that the petitioners came to know all
 these facts only in December 1961, even then there has
 been inordinate delay in presenting the present petition.
 The fact that Jaisinghani's case, 1967-2 SCR 703 = (AIR
 1967 SC 1427) was pending before the High Court and
 later in this Court is also no excuse for the delay in
 presenting the present petition. In the result, the petition
 fails and is dismissed. There will be no order as to costs."
Mr. Ghosh then cited a decision reported in A.I.R.
1989 S.C. 690 (Union of India and others Vs. M/s. Suksha
International and M/s. Nutan Gems and another).
Paragraph 11 of the aforementioned judgement as referred
by Mr. Ghosh reads as follows :-

"11. Shri Subba Rao would say that the reference in
 the order by learned single Judge to the contention on the
 point of delay as bar to relief had nothing to9 do with the
 specific contention of the appellants that there was
 inordinate and unexplained delay in approaching the
 Court. This learned counsel submits, would be clear, by
 a reference to the aspect of the delay dealt with and
 considered in W.P. 2477 of 1984, on which the learned
 single Judge relied. The order of the same learned single
 Judge in W.P. 2477 of 1984, in which the particular
 aspect of delay is considered is at para 8 of that order.
 That para in the order in W.P. 2477 of 1984 reads :

'Mr. Joshi, learned counsel for the respondents,
 submitted that the petitioners were not entitled
 to relief because of delay. It is not possible to
 agree. After the redemption certificate of 16th
 November, 1983, application for revalidation

and OGL endorsement was made within four
 months therefrom on 12th March, 1984. There
 is, in the circumstances, no such delay as to
 warrant its rejection on that ground. The
 contention thus fails and is rejected.' "
Mr. Ghosh also referred another judgement cited in

A.I.R.1989 S.C. 2082 (
T.R. Kapoor and others Vs. State of

Haryana and others
). The relevant portion of the
judgement which was referred by Mr. Ghosh reads as
follows :-

" Held that the petitioners had acquiesced in the
 interpretation of the Rules by the State Government all
 along and it was only after the decision of the Supreme
 Court disapproving the interpretation placed by the State
 on the Rules they chose to move the Supreme Court
 under 
Art. 32
 of the Constitution to seek promotional
 benefits. Having remained complacent for a long number
 of years, the petitioners cannot now turn round and say
 that notwithstanding their inaction, they should be
 granted promotion from deemed dates on the basis of
 seniority."
The other judgement cited by Mr. Ghosh is reported
in (2010) 7 S.C.C. 525 (Maresh Kumar Vs. Department of
Atomic Energy and others). Paragraph 15 of the said
judgement reads as follows :-

"15. Merely because the case of the appellant was
 forwarded by the Department vide its Letter dated 27-1-
 2007 for favourable consideration, would not vest any

right in the petitioner and can hardly be of any materials
 consequence. If an employee keeps making representation
 after representation which are consistently rejected then
 the appellant cannot claim any relief on that ground. We
 are unable to find any merit in the contention raised
 before us and we are also of the view that the High Court
 was not in error while dismissing the writ petition even on
 the ground of unexplained delay and laches. The
 representation of the appellant was rejected as back in
 the year 1999 and for the reasons best known to the
 appellant he did not challenge the same before the court
 of competent jurisdiction."
Mr. Ghosh also cited the decision of the Hon'ble Apex

Court reported in (2006) 4 S.C.C. 327 (
Kerala Samsthana

Chethu Thozhilali Union Vs. State of Kerala and others
).
Relevant paragraphs 8, 9 and 10 read as follows :-

"8. It would be appropriate to note certain decisions
 of this Court in which this aspect has been dealt with in
 relation to 
Article 32
 of the Constitution. It is apparent
 that what has been stated as regards that article would
 apply, a fortiori, to 
Article 226.
 It was observed in
 
Rabindranath Bose v. Union of India
 that no relief can be
 given to the petitioner who without any reasonable
 explanation approaches this Court under 
Article 32
 after
 inordinate delay. It was stated that though 
Article 32
 is
 itself a guaranteed right, it does not follow from this that
 it was the intention of the Constitution-makers that this
 Court should disregard all principles and grant relief in
 petitions filed after inordinate delay.

9. It was stated in 
State of M.P. v. Nandlal Jaiswal
that the High Court in exercise of its discretion

does not ordinarily assist the tardy and the
 indolent or the acquiescent and the lethargic. If
 there is inordinate delay on the part of the
 petitioner and such delay is not satisfactorily
 explained, the High Court may decline to
 intervene and grant relief in exercise of its writ
 jurisdiction. It was stated that this rule is
 premised on a number of factors. The High Court
 does not ordinarily permit a belated resort to the
 extraordinary remedy because it is likely to cause
 confusion and public inconvenience and bring, in
 its train new injustices, and if writ jurisdiction is
 exercised after unreasonable delay, it may have
 the effect of inflicting not only hardship and
 inconvenience but also injustice on third parties.
 It was pointed out that when writ jurisdiction is
 invoked, unexplained delay coupled with the
 creation of third-party rights in the meantime is
 an important factor which also weighs with the
 High Court in deciding whether or not to exercise
 such jurisdiction.

10. It has been pointed out by this Court in a number
 of cases that representations would not be
 adequate explanation to take care of delay. This
 was first stated in K.V. Rajalakshmiah Setty v.

State of Mysore. This was reiterated in
 
Rabindranath Bose
 case by stating that there is a
 limit to the time which can be considered
 reasonable for making representations and if the
 government had turned down one representation
 the making of another representation on similar
 lines will not explain the delay.
 
In 
State of Orissa
 v. Pyarimohan Samantaray
 making of repeated

representations was not regarded as satisfactory
 explanation of the delay. In that case the petition
 had been dismissed for delay alone."
The last judgement cited by Mr. Ghose is A.I.R. 1974
The relevant passage placed by Mr. Ghose reads as
follows :-

" Brief Note :- (A) Where a Government servant slept
 over the promotions of his juniors over his head for
 fourteen years and then approached the High Court with
 writ petition challenging the relaxation of relevant rules in
 favour of the juniors, the writ petition is liable to be
 dismissed in limine. Such an aggrieved person should
 approach the Court at least within six months or at the
 most a year of promotion of his juniors.

It is not that there is any period of limitation for
 the Courts to exercise their powers under 
Art. 226
, nor is
 it that there can never be a case where the Courts cannot
 interfere in a matter after the passage of a certain length
 of time. But it would be a sound and wise exercise of
 discretion for the Courts to refuse to exercise their
 extraordinary powers under 
Art. 226
 in the case of
 persons who do not approach it expeditiously for relief and
 who stand by and allow things to happen and then
 approach the Court to put forward stale claims and try to
 unsettle settled matters. Decision in W.P. and Appeal
 (Mad.) ...... ".
I have carefully considered the submissions made by
the learned Counsel appearing for the respective parties as
well as the materials available on record. It appears from
records that the writ petitioner was appointed as Manager
on probation at sub-office in scale of 400-1020/- on 19th
Septembers, 1977. He was confirmed after about two
years i.e. on 1st June, 1979 in the scale of Rs.400-1020/-.
In view of Bank Nationalization Act, the respondent, the
New Bank of India, the employer of the writ petitioner, was
also nationalised on 15th April, 1981. Officers Service
Regulations brought into operation on and from 1st
January, 1983. Categorisation was made pursuant to such
regulation and the writ petitioner was categorised in
Junior Management Group Scale-I and placed in the
seniority list on that scale. The petitioner made
representation in July 25, 1983 against Categorisation.
The concerned respondent thereafter prepared the
seniority list on 1st January, 1994. The respondent also
did not allow the writ petitioner to participate in the
promotion process held in March, 1985 but the writ
petitioner did not question the same before any court of
law rather he made another representation in June 24,
1984. Thereafter, again he made appeal for fitment in
Middle Management Group Scale-II on 1st July, 1987.
However, the respondent authorities issued a letter of
refusal on 19th February, 1990. The writ petitioner then
also remained silent. Thereafter, the selection process was
held for giving promotion and on the basis of invitation of
the respondent authorities the writ petitioner participated
in the promotion process from Junior Management Group
Scale-I to Middle Management Group Scale-II and he was
selected and he got promotion as well as grade to Middle
Management Group Scale-II. Thereafter, he once again
made an appeal before the higher authorities i.e. before the
Chairman and the Managing Director on October 31, 1992
and the respondent Bank replied to the representation of
the writ petitioner stating therein the reply dated 9th
November, 1992 that against the decision of Sainathan
they have preferred a review application before the Hon'ble
Apex Court which is pending. Therefore, the case cannot
be considered at that stage. The review application was
again rejected by the Hon'ble Supreme Court on 5th March,
1993 and the writ petitioner asked the concerned
respondent to reconsider his case. However, the writ
petitioner at that stage even did not come up before the
Hon'ble Court questioning the action on the side of the
respondent. The writ petitioner thereafter again made
representation and has waited till January, 1996 and only
in February, 1996 filed this writ petition claiming seniority
and gradation with effect from 19th September, 1977 on
the basis of the decision of S. Sainathan. Although
Sainathan's case was decided by Andhra Pradesh High
Court in 1987 the writ petitioner also did not question the
action of the respondent authorities after 1987. In this
way the writ petitioner continued in the promotional post
and got all subsequent benefits on that basis and in fact,
retired from service after completion of the entire service
tenure. It appears from the aforementioned action that the
cause of action in fact arose in 1984 when he was not
called for participation in promotion process and when his
seniority list was prepared in the category of Junior Group
Scale-I. He also did not come up and question the same in
1987. The learned Single Judge delivered in 1987 in
Sainathan's case. The writ petitioner also did not come
and question the action of the respondent authorities on
the basis of the said judgement. He waited for a long
thirteen years till before February, 1996. There is no
acceptable explanation for the delay in the writ petition.
Further making repeated representations without taking
any legal action in appropriate time, is not at all an
explanation for the delay. In case of Naresh Kumar (supra)
the Hon'ble Supreme Court have clearly held that if an
employee keeps making representation after representation
which are consistently rejected then the appellant cannot
claim any relief on that ground and the Hon'ble Apex
Court refused to grant any relief in favour of the aggrieved

party. 
In case of 
Keralasamsthana Chethu Thozhilali

Union
 (supra) it was held if the writ jurisdiction is
exercised after unreasonable delay, it may have the effect
of inflicting not only hardship and inconvenience but also
injustice on third parties. It was also pointed out that
when the writ jurisdiction is invoked, unexplained delay
coupled with the creation of third-party rights in the
meantime is an important factor which also weighs with
the High Court in deciding whether or not to exercise such
jurisdiction.
In my view, the writ petitioner went on making
representation one after another and at the same time has
accepted the categorisation in Junior Management Group
Scale-I and also accepted promotion given by the
respondent-Bank in 1991 and continued till the date of
retirement. Only after a lapse of 13 years he made this
writ petition taking a plea of similar status with Sainathan
and claimed relief with effect from 1977. In my view, the
writ petitioner suffers inordinate unexplained delay.
Therefore, the writ petition is not maintainable.
It is pertinent to mention that after the refusal of
consideration of representation in 1990 the writ petitioner
at the call of the respondent authorities appeared at the
promotional process and having been selected accepted
such promotion with effect from 1991. Although he has
made some representations thereafter but it appears that
he has waived all his rights by accepting such promotion
and also by not questioning the impugned action in 1984
when the promotional list was prepared and thereafter in
1987 when the judgement was delivered in case of
Sainathan and thereafter when the process of selection
started in 1991 for giving promotion.
In that view of the matter the writ petitioner loses his
claim to have any benefit on and from 1977.
On the point of similarity in status and claiming
similar benefits as was given to Sainathan is concerned,
from a bare perusal of the writ petition as well as reply, the
writ petitioner could not explain before this Court in what
manner he is similarly situated. However, an argument
was advanced that the writ petitioner is similarly situated

like S. Sainathan but the comparison between 
S.
Sainathan and P.K. Sharma as submitted by Mr. Ghosh
makes some difference and distinction between them.
Therefore, on that score also the writ petitioner is not
entitled to get any benefit. Otherwise also it appears that
on similar ground some other employees moved an

application under 
Article 32
 of the Constitution before the
Hon'ble Apex Court to have the same benefit which was
dismissed by the Hon'ble Apex Court. There is other
proceeding also which was initiated by some other
employees before Punjab and Haryana High Court, which
was although allowed by the learned Single Judge but
subsequently the order of the learned Single Judge was set
aside and the writ petition was dismissed.
In view of my aforementioned findings this writ
petition must fail. Therefore, the writ petition is dismissed.
However, there would be no order as to costs.
Urgent photostat certified copy of this order, if
applied for, be furnished to the appearing parties on
priority basis.
(Ashoke Kumar Dasadhikari, J.)
